How big is big? In states that have enacted so called "tort reform" MD malpractice premiums have not decreased significantly nor have patient costs. What has changed is that if you are a victim of medical negligence or malpractice, you may be unable to find legal representation.

Perhaps you should read the ProPublica article on how difficult it is to prove malpractice--because MDs are so unwilling to testify against each other. http://www.propublica.org/article/why-doctors-stay-mum-about-mistakes-th... Or how upset some MDs are about Oregon's forcing MDs to disclose their potential bias/conflict of interest when discussing medical devices w/their patients--if the MD is making more money if the patient chooses on brand of device.

And then there's the refusal of both surgeons and medical device manufacturers (and the FDA) to pull some metal on metal hip replacements until--oh wait--they not only received a huge number of complaints but class action litigation revealed the full extent of the problem.

Those lawyers, horrible how they assist people whose pain & suffering otherwise would be ignored--by their physicians, by corporations, by the FDA.

Racism is receding, but its root keeps producing virulent offshoots such as global warming denial and dismissal of the poor. As you said so clearly, it's love that we must never lose sight of. Now that we're getting deeper into the holidays, your message today puts a log of things in perspective.
And if you're proved wrong, will you admit it?

You are ignoring that there are NOW 5 million surgeries each week. In the present health financing arrangement many of these are on the uninsured. Tens of thousands uninsured presently receive hospital invoices and are charged tens of thousands of dollars. Often, other people believe that they have insurance that will help them; and then it won't. They all face financial ruin, and that is why developing a health problem is the most common reason people in the USA file for bankruptcy now.

This is not what will begin in 2014. What will begin in 2014 is intended to improve on this present situation. If the sins of our present situation are visited on the Affordable Care Act in 2014, we will have further work to do to root out these problems and make our health system effective.

What has been underway since 2010 has been a process transforming the health system. We have already reaped benefits and more will ensue. I agree that thus far there exists continued gaming of the system, but that too will change.

With roughly five million surgeries started each week, the crises will be just beginning in January.

Calculate the average cost of a surgical procedure times the number of people that believe they have insurance - yet do not or times the number of people who will have lost their insurance.....The numbers suggest that there may be an even bigger crisis on the horizon.

Simple math suggest that by next June tens of thousands of people will be receiving hospital invoices costing tens of thousands of dollars. Secondly, the clock keeps ticking on millions of people currently on employer based health insurance policies that are likely to be receiving notices that their plans are being cancelled or at the very least be repriced....this is not exactly going be have the same impression of receiving a postcard from the Publishing House Sweepstakes company.

Before the hospitals start sending the bills, I suggest that a bipartisan provision to the ACA be implemented that would Insure that everyone is insured for 2014. Then scrap Obamacare and rebuild America's Care - a healthcare plan that can be enacted by 2015.

In order for this to happen, we have to have leaders that are more concerned about ideals than idealism.

1) Do you want to save the planet? Yes / No / Not sure

The planet does not need to be saved it will be OK no matter what so this question is invalid. You probably mean do you want to spend a lot of money and effort to mitigate conditions that might kill more people and species than doing nothing. Answer with current knowledge is NO!!

2) Are Human GHGs driving Climate Change? Yes / No / Not sure

Well I don't understand what you might mean by "driving Climate Change". By my understanding that would mean that temperatures go up directly with the increases we see. Since that is not happening the answer is also NO!!

3) Would you be happier if the abrupt climate jolts / shifts / surprises in the coming decade(s) were to:

a) stay constant or fall (no tipping points reached)?
b) rise (tipping points reached)?
c) not sure?

I would be happier if we actually knew something about the climate that would be useful in identifying "abrupt climate jolts". I would be happy to never have such.

I believe in "science", but science requires experiments to validate hypothesis or at least very good predictions. Climate "science" has neither as of now. The climate system is way too complex and the effects of the various attributes (not considering their interactions) for acceptable analysis.

Maybe it's the age difference but my white 8 yr old had no trouble understanding who Nelson Mandela was and how important he is to the world. She spent part of yesterday's snow day reading about him for a "book" she wants to write.

Previous discussions in the NY Times, maybe even this column, have been very helpful. We moved beyond "people come in all colors". Discussing MLK and how not everyone has been, or is, treated fairly opens her eyes to reality. We expect her to be respectful but noticing differences is not racist. Our world; friends, school, and community are incredibly diverse. How we treat folks is an example for her, and she would definitely notice if folks of color were somehow different.

Thanks for this thoughtful piece. I was crying explaining to my 5 year old why our nation was morning the loss of Nelson Mandela today.  It is hard to explain enough so they understand without traumatizing them with the entire history of oppression and violence that is racism in South Africa or the US. As a white woman raising a white daughter, I feel a special responsibility to help her understand equity and her role in shaping justice in the future, but how to do that is rarely clear to me, even as I do my best. Tough stuff.

Although I was shocked at first when I read that he'd turned down the vice president’s offer, I then understood it (as did Mr. Biden): Mr. Newman is 85 years old, and had been held against his will for nearly six weeks. He wasn’t looking for an “adventure” — he simply wanted to return home ASAP. Beijing to San Francisco is a 12-hour flight, and in order to fly there directly, he would need a jumbo jet, and Air Force 2 (or 1, for that matter) is hardly a jumbo jet.

Being “naïve, political or incredibly ungrateful” had nothing to do with it. Instead, I think Mr. Newman was being both realistic and practical (and anything BUT political). He realized that his time is limited and he wanted to get home to his wife — a sentiment that Mr. Biden, mensch that he is, totally got: “I don’t blame him. I’d be on that flight, too.”

For someone supposedly interested in 'exotic' places and unusual adventures, it seems strange to turn down a very unique opportunity to fly back an Air Force 2 vs. a commercial flight with a more crowded ,much less comfortable seating/meal arrangement... Naïve, political, or incredibly ungrateful for the work done to release him?? I'm sure the right wing will play up his refusal to accompany the Vice President. Incredible!

"But what I don't understand is why Democrats are reluctant to cut costs by simply producing more doctors."

It's not just democrats. The AMA contributes to both parties (the winning party gets the most) to influence the persistence of protectionist policies that ensure a shortage of doctors. As you say, if supply is low relative to demand, then prices go up, even if its a market manipulation by the medical profession.

Another item you didn't mention is the high cost of pharmaceuticals, far beyond the fair recompense for the pharma's portion of R&D (most of which is born by public institutions such as NIH and public universities). $3 per treatment versus $3000 per treatment would lead to substantial savings and keep wonder drugs accessible to the poor.

@Richard

If you're intimating we need stimulus so we can finally wean off QE, I'm there with you. If you're also intimating that we should have gone with universal health, then I've been there from the get-go!

We also need to invent/generate new higher paying U.S. jobs that force the low paying service industries into competition for workers. That would pull wages up and might work better than simply trying to push them up. How, I do not know. I only can offer some layman's guesses to prompt those smarter than me to start thinking.

One way might be to mandate balanced international trade (importers must buy $ trade credits from exporters that have earned them.) To avoid that added cost importers might try harder to produce here rather than abroad. A second might be to launch a program to renew our crumbling public infrastructure, thus creating competing and higher paying construction jobs. A third might be to generate research centers that are focused on developing new products with the patents government owned and licensed only to companies that manufacture those products here, for domestic consumptions and export.

This Congress will do nothing. The GOP is hell-bent on destroying the safety net. Its backers have been busy justifying to their supporters, through lies and deception of every kind imaginable and unimaginable for months now. You have the so-called papers put out by Heritage. You have the budgets and speeches put out by Paul Ryan. You have the religious doctrine put out by such right-wing fundamentalist organizations as The Family Research Council, reinterpreting the gospel to advocate deep cuts in the safety net. The propaganda has been constant. Mother Jones reported about a new coordinated assault by a network of right-wing think tanks that is about to begin*. The targets? Worker's rights, Medicaid, and education.

From now and until the end of the Election 2014 season, the New York Times editorials should focus on practical ways the Democratic party and left-leaning organizations can get the message out to the voting public. Obstruction and nullification must end. The only way those will end is by removing the GOP from the majority in the House of Representatives and wherever possible in the states where they dominate all three branches of government.

* Mother Jones: http://www.motherjones.com/mojo/2013/12/state-policy-network-assault-wor...

The only people who might benefit from e-cigarettes are those who are already addicted to smoking regular cigarettes. So regulate e-cigarettes so that they can be purchased by anyone who can legally purchase regular cigarettes.

There is no need to relax regulations to allow e-cigs to be vaped where smoking is currently prohibited. Make those who smoke or vape do so away from others who do not want to be exposed to smoke or even vapor.

And by continuing the stigma associated with smoking, it will discourage those who don't already smoke from taking up vaping. Why make the habit of vaping look cool and stylish to kids? So they can become addicted?

Clearly, the e-cig industry (i.e. the tobacco industry) would like to see the market for e-cigs grow to the point that it is larger than that for regular cigarettes. But there is no reason to allow or encourage this, as it has no real benefit for anyone - other than profit greedy tobacco executives.
